The origin of social and preventive medicine dates back to the 18th century. It began even before the germ theory had been proposed.
Solution to Question 2:
Chinese medicine claims to be the world's first organized body of medical knowledge. It dates back to 2700 B.C. They are also considered to be the pioneers of immunization (used variolation against smallpox).
Modern Chinese medicine includes barefoot doctors and acupuncture.
Solution to Question 3:
The Ministry of AYUSH was established to regulate the fields of Ayurveda, Yoga, and Naturopathy, Unani, Siddha, and Homeopathy.

The Ayurveda, Siddha, and Yoga systems of medicine are of Indian origin. Ayurveda means knowledge of life. Its origin can be traced back to 5000 B.C (Vedic times). The medical knowledge in the Atharvaveda eventually developed into Ayurveda.
The Unani system is of Greek origin.

Similia similibus curentur or human drug pathogenicity study: Treatment of disease using small amounts of drug that, in healthy people, would produce similar symptoms of the disease itself.
A single medicine is used for the treatment.

Solution to Question 16:
Edwin Chadwick was the architect of the Public Health Act of 1848.
He was an English lawyer during the 1832 cholera epidemic. He compiled a report on the Sanitary Condition of the Labouring Population in Great Britain that eventually led to the passing of this act. It is considered a landmark act in the history of public health.
Solution to Question 17:
Robert Koch discovered that anthrax was caused by bacteria.
He also discovered the causative agents of tuberculosis and cholera. He won the Nobel prize in Physiology in 1905.
He also proposed Koch's postulates linking specific microorganisms to specific diseases. They state that the microorganism must be:
Found in abundance in diseased organisms, but not in healthy organisms.
Isolated from a diseased organism and grown in pure culture
Able to cause disease when inoculated into a healthy organism
Re-isolated from the diseased experimental host and identical to the original specific causative agent

Solution to Question 19:
The first bacterium discovered as a cause of the disease is leprosy bacillus.
In 1873, Armauer Hansen demonstrated Mycobacterium leprae (rod-like bodies) from a leprosy nodule. This is the first time that chronic infectious disease in humans was shown to be related to a bacillus.
In 1876, Robert Koch validated the germ theory of disease after discovering the anthrax bacillus as the cause of anthrax.

The last case of smallpox occurred in 1978 when a medical photographer was accidentally exposed to the smallpox virus in a research laboratory in Birmingham.
India was declared smallpox-free on 24th May 1975. WHO declared smallpox as eradicated globally on 8th May 1980.

Solution to Question 1:
According to the WHO, health is “a state of complete physical, mental and social well-being and not merely the absence of disease or infirmity”.
In recent years, the definition has been modified to also include the ability to lead a “socially and economically productive life.”
Solution to Question 2:
The biomedical concept of disease is based on the germ theory of disease, which was postulated by Louis Pasteur.
The germ theory of disease states that microorganisms known as pathogens or germs can lead to disease. It was criticized that it did not include environmental, social, psychological, and cultural determinants of health.
The ecological concept of disease states that disease is the maladjustment of the human organism to the environment.
The psychosocial concept of disease hypothesised that health is also influenced by social, psychological, cultural and economic factors as well.
The holistic concept of disease includes all the above concepts to describe health.
Solution to Question 3:
Life expectancy is a positive mortality indicator.
A set of values that measure the rate of mortality or death is known as mortality indicators.
Disability-adjusted life years (DALY), health adjusted life expectancy (HALE), and Sullivan’s Index are disability rates.
Solution to Question 4:
Number of days of restricted activity is a disability indicator.
Morbidity is defined as public health outcomes focusing on diseases, traumas, or injury. Morbidity indicators can be used to measure the overall health and extent of healthcare utilisation in a given population.
Disability is defined as public health outcomes related to health conditions that include limitations in personal activities and societal participation. There are two types of disability indicators as follows:
Event type indicators-
Number of days of restricted activity
Bed disability days
Work loss days (or school loss days) within a specified period
Person type indicators-
Limitation of mobility: e.g confined to bed
Limitation of activity: e.g limitation to perform the basic activities of daily living such as eating and going to the toilet
Solution to Question 5:
HALE (Health Adjusted Life Expectancy) is an indicator that can be used to estimate the number of years a newborn is expected to live in full health based on the current rates of ill health and mortality.
HALE is calculated using the life expectancy at birth with an adjustment for time spent in poor health. It captures both fatal and non-fatal health outcomes of average levels of population health. It is also sensitive to changes over time or differences between countries in the distribution of health states.
Sullivan's index is also known as disability-free life expectancy (DFLE) or active life expectancy. It is the average number of years an individual is expected to live free of disability if the current patterns of mortality and disability continue to apply. It doesn’t take into account premature death. As HALE includes not just disability but the larger definition of poor health, it is a better option with respect to the question.
Solution to Question 6:
The proportional mortality rate is the simplest measure of estimating the burden of disease in the community. It signifies the proportion of all deaths that can be attributed to the disease.
It is calculated as follows:
Proportional mortality rate of a disease = (No. of deaths due to that disease in the year/ Total no. of deaths in the year) *100.
Option A: Case fatality rate measures the risk of persons dying from a certain disease within a given time period. It measures the killing power of a disease. It is used to link mortality to morbidity.
Option B: Incidence measures the rate at which new cases are occurring in a population. It is not influenced by the duration of the disease. The use of incidence is generally restricted to acute diseases.
Option C: Crude death rate is considered a fair indicator of the comparative health of the people. It is the rate of total deaths in a year compared to the mid-year population.
Solution to Question 7:
Disability adjusted life years (DALY) is the best measure of the overall burden of a disease in a defined population. It is also the best measure of the effectiveness of interventions.
DALY is calculated as - Years of lost life prematurely (YLL) + Years lost to disability (YLD). It can measure both mortality and disability together.
As DALY is affected by premature loss of life, conditions that affect younger individuals like road traffic accidents have a high DALY. In comparison to this, Alzheimer's disease has a lower DALY as it is a disease that mostly develops during old age and so has a lower YLL.
Solution to Question 8:
Bed disability days is not a utilisation rate. It is an event-type disability indicator. It is defined as the number of days a person spent in a hospital bed due to illness or injury.
Health utilisation rate is defined as the number of people making use of the available health services to the total number of individuals in that population.
Health utilisation rates include:
Proportion of infants immunized against 9 diseases in the expanded program on immunization
(EPI)
Proportion of women receiving antenatal care and supervised delivery
Percentage of population using family planning methods
Bed occupancy rate
Average length of stay in the hospita
Bed turnover ratio
Solution to Question 9:
For optimum utilization of health services in a hospital, bed turnover interval must always be slightly positive.
Bed turnover interval is defined as the time interval where a hospital bed is
left unoccupied following a patient’s discharge till the next patient occupies it after admission.
Solution to Question 10:
Infant mortality rate (IMR) is the best indicator of the availability, utilization, and effectiveness of health care. It is a very sensitive indicator.
Infant mortality rate (IMR)= Number of deaths in the first year of life/Number of live births x 1000
It is also one of the best indicators of state failure. It is the most universally accepted health status indicator of the whole population and of the socio-economic status in which they live.

Solution to Question 1:
Duration of illness is not a part of the epidemiological triad for tuberculosis. The epidemiological triad includes host, agent and environment:
Host factors: Age, sex, religion, race, genetic profile, immune system
Agent factors:
Biological - bacteria, viruses
Chemical - poisons, alcohol, smoke
Physical - trauma, fire, radiation
Nutrition - lack/excess
Environmental factors:
Temperature, humidity, altitude
Water, milk, food
Radiation, pollution, noise
Crowding, housing, neighborhood

Hence, a malnourished child (host), Mycobacterium tuberculosis (agent) and overcrowding
(environment) form the epidemiological triad for tuberculosis.

Solution to Question 2:
Disease  Impairment  Disability  Handicap is the most logical sequence among the given options.
Disease is a state of physiological/psychological dysfunction. Impairment is any loss or abnormality in normal structure or function. Disability is the inability to carry out normal actions due to impairment.
Handicap is the disadvantage due to disability that limits fulfilment of a role that is normal.

Solution to Question 3:
The correctly matched events relating to the given example are as follows:
The WHO definition of impairment is "any loss or abnormality of psychological, physiological or anatomical structure or function". E.g., loss of a foot. An initial impairment may cause a secondary impairment as well.
The WHO defines disability as ''any restriction or lack of ability to perform an activity in the manner or within the range considered normal for a human being". Because of impairment, the affected person may be unable to carry out certain activities and hence the person is considered disabled.
According to the WHO, a handicap is "a disadvantage for a given individual, resulting from an impairment or a disability, that limits or prevents the fulfilment of a role that is normal (depending on age, sex, and social and cultural factors) for that individual". The disadvantages experienced by a person as a result of disability makes them handicapped.

The web of causation for a disease suggests a number of ways to interrupt the disease occurrence/progression.
This model was suggested by MacMahon and Pugh in their book ‘Epidemiologic Principles and Methods’.
Web of causation considers all the predisposing factors and their complex interrelationship with each other. This model is ideally suited in the study of chronic disease. The web of causation does not imply that the disease is controlled only when all the multiple chains of causation are removed. Sometimes removal of one significant link is sufficient to control the disease.
In a multifactorial event, individual factors are by no means of equal weightage. The importance of each factor is expressed in terms of relative risk.
Solution to Question 5:
Primary prevention is not possible in the pathogenesis period of a disease. It can only be done in the period of pre-pathogenesis.
The two phases in the natural history of a disease include:
Period of pre-pathogenesis: It is before the onset of disease in humans. The disease agent has not entered the host, but the factors favouring the disease already exist. Primary
prevention (health promotion and specific protection) is applicable in this period.
Period of pathogenesis: It begins with the entry of the organism till recovery, death or disability. Secondary (halting of the disease process) and tertiary prevention (measures to limit disability) are applicable in this period. It isn't always characterised by the presence of disease symptoms as it also includes subclinical cases.

Solution to Question 8:
Interruption in the transmission of a disease is called elimination. It is a step towards eradication.
Elimination is a reduction in the number of new cases of an infectious disease to zero (or a very low defined target rate) in a defined geographical area as a result of deliberate efforts. Continued measures to prevent re-establishment of transmission are required.
Eradication is a complete and permanent worldwide reduction to zero new cases of an infectious disease through deliberate efforts. No further control measures are required.
Surveillance is the continuous scrutiny of factors that determine the occurrence and distribution of disease and ill health.
Control aims at decreasing the incidence, duration and transmission of the disease. It also aims at decreasing the physical and psychological complications of a disease.
Solution to Question 9:
Herd immunity aids the most in disease elimination.
Herd immunity achieved, especially through immunization, goes a long way in helping the elimination of diseases. When a high level of herd immunity is maintained, the susceptible population is reduced to a small proportion, thereby eliminating the disease.
The purpose of isolation is to protect the community by preventing the transfer of infection from the reservoir to the possible susceptible hosts. Quarantine refers to restrictions on the healthy contacts of an infectious disease.

Control aims at decreasing the incidence, duration and transmission of the disease. It also aims at decreasing the physical and psychological complications of a disease.
The iceberg phenomenon of disease is related to the spectrum of disease. The submerged portion of the iceberg represents the hidden mass of diseases like asymptomatic, latent, and undiagnosed cases. The difference between analytical studies and randomised controlled trials is that in the former there is no randomisation because it requires the participants to be divided into diseased and non-diseased. This can lead to a number of biases that are avoided in RCTs.
Solution to Question 2:

In an RCT, participants are randomly assigned to a study group or a control group. It is done only after obtaining consent. It removes both known and unknown confounding factors.
The heart of a randomized controlled trial (RCT) is randomisation. This allows comparability between the study and the control population.
Solution to Question 3:

It ignores noncompliance, protocol change, withdrawal, cross-over, and anything that happens after randomization during analysis. The exclusion of dropouts may lead to the introduction
of bias.
Note: Per-protocol analysis is a comparison of treatment groups that include only those patients who completed the treatment originally allocated to them. Hence, comparability between the study and control group is limited and randomisation is lost.

Solution to Question 5:

In a cross over study design, patients are randomly assigned to the study and control group, and then after a period of time, their groups are switched. Here, each patient serves as his/her own control which allows for maximum comparability.
In a concurrent parallel study design, comparisons are made between two randomly assigned groups and there is no switching of groups. This allows only for limited comparability between experimental and control groups.
Quasi-experiments are studies that aim to evaluate interventions but that do not use randomization. The lack of randomisation is the major weakness of quasi trials. The comparability in a quasi trial is limited.
A per-protocol analysis is a comparison of treatment groups that include only those patients who completed the treatment originally allocated. Hence, comparability is limited.

Solution to Question 2:
Chronic carriers are those who shed or excrete the organism for indefinite periods. Carriers are classified into chronic carriers and temporary carriers based on the duration.
Organisms may be shed continuously or intermittently in chronic carriers. The duration of the carrier state also depends on the disease. Chronic carrier state is seen in typhoid, hepatitis B, gonorrhea, malaria, etc.
Temporary carriers are classified into:
Incubatory carriers - Those that shed the organism during the incubation period of the disease, especially during the later parts of it. It is seen in measles, mumps, polio, etc.
Healthy carriers - Those who suffer from subclinical infections and develop a carrier state without developing the overt disease. It is seen in polio, meningococcal meningitis, cholera, diphtheria, etc.
Convalescent carriers - Those that shed the organism during recovery or convalescence. It is seen in typhoid.
Paradoxical carrier refers to a carrier who acquires the pathogen from another carrier. Note: Pseudo-carriers are carriers of avirulent organisms.

The expelled droplets may impinge directly upon the conjunctiva, oro-respiratory mucosa or skin of close contact. This mode of transmission is seen in common cold, diphtheria, etc.

The droplet nuclei may remain airborne for long periods of time, some retaining and others losing infectivity or virulence. These small particles when inhaled are capable of reaching the alveoli and getting retained there.

The probability that infection will occur among susceptible persons following contact with an infectious person within the incubation period is called secondary attack rate.
It is calculated by the following formula:
Secondary attack rate (SAR) = (Number of exposed or susceptible persons developing the disease within the incubation period x 100)/(Total number of close or exposed contacts that are susceptible)
Primary cases are usually excluded from the numerator and denominator. Secondary attack rate measures the communicability of the disease.

Solution to Question 1:
It is not possible to achieve 100% herd immunity against a certain disease but studies have shown this is not necessary for disease control.
Herd structure is never constant. It is subject to constant variation because of new births, deaths and population mobility. An ongoing immunization programme will keep up the herd immunity at a very high level.
Solution to Question 2:
Herd immunity threshold does not vary with the number of vaccines for the disease. It varies only due to the virulence of the disease, efficacy of the vaccine and contact parameter for the population.
Solution to Question 3:
Live vaccines should generally be avoided for 12 weeks following an injection of normal human immunoglobulin (Ig). If a live vaccine has already been administered, the injection of normal human Ig should be delayed for 2 weeks.
NHIG is an antibody-rich fraction that is usually obtained from a pool of at least 1,000 donors. AN NHIG preparation must contain at least 90% intact IgG and minimal IgG aggregates with low IgA concentration. NHIG is commonly used to prevent measles and hepatitis A infections.
Specific human immunoglobulins are made from the plasma of patients who have recently recovered from an infection or are obtained from individuals who have been immunized against a specific infection. These preparations have a high antibody content against an individual infection and provide immediate protection.
Solution to Question 4:
Specific human immunoglobulins or hyperimmune human Igs are obtained from selected donors that have high titres of the antibodies to the disease like those who have recovered from the disease.
It is commonly used in prophylaxis of chickenpox in highly susceptible individuals and in post-exposure prophylaxis of hepatitis B.
Solution to Question 5:
Production of antibodies is faster in secondary booster response.
Primary response is the immune response developed when an antigen is administered for the first time to a person who has never been exposed to it. There is a latent period of 3-10 days before antibodies appear in the blood.
Secondary booster response is the immune response elicited by a booster dose. In comparison to a primary immune response, it has a shorter latent period, faster production of antibodies, and
an abundance of antibodies. The antibody response is maintained at higher levels for a longer period of time, and the antibody elicited tends to have a greater avidity or capacity to bind to the antigen.
Solution to Question 6:
Simultaneous administration of vaccines is defined as administering more than one vaccine on the same clinic day, at different anatomic sites. They are not combined in the same syringe.
Simultaneous administration of the most widely used live and inactivated vaccines does not result in decreased antibody responses or increased rates of adverse reaction. However, in children with functional or anatomic asplenia pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV13) and Menactra brand meningococcal conjugate vaccines should not be administered at the same visit; separate these vaccines by at least 4 weeks.
Advantages of simultaneous administration of vaccines:
The organisms multiply in the host and thus, the antigenic dose is larger than what is injected.
They have all the major and minor antigenic components.
Live vaccines should not be administered to those with an immunocompromised state, since they may cause severe systemic disease by way of viremia/bacteriemia.
Note: If live vaccines are not given simultaneously, they must be spaced as follows-
The administration of two live parenteral vaccines or live intranasal influenza vaccines must be separated by at least 4 weeks (28 days).
If two live vaccines are given less than 4 weeks apart, the second vaccine should be repeated in four weeks. This is because the live vaccine given first can interfere with the second vaccine, and the person may not develop active immunity to the second vaccine.
Solution to Question 7:
Yellow fever vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine.
Injectable polio vaccine (Salk vaccine), pertussis vaccine, and rabies vaccine are killed vaccines.
Solution to Question 8:
The only absolute contraindication to administration of an inactivated or killed vaccine is severe local or general reaction to a previous dose of the vaccine.
Inactivated or killed vaccines are made from growing cultures of the organism and then inactivating them with heat or chemicals.They activate the channels of active immunity after injection and are less efficacious than live vaccines. Multiple doses or booster doses are usually required to produce an adequate antibody response.
Killed vaccines can be given to immune-compromised individuals and in pregnancy as the infective agent is inactivated and cannot grow.
Egg allergy is not an absolute contraindication to the administration of an inactivated or killed vaccine.

HBV and HPV vaccines are recombinant vaccines. Tetanus vaccine is a toxoid vaccine.

The minimum interval between the administration of two live vaccines is 4 weeks.
This is because decreasing the interval between two doses may interfere with the antibody response and protection. Thus, live vaccines can either be given on the same day according to the schedule or 4 weeks apart.
Note: In Park 27th ed. the minimum interval between two live vaccines is given as 3 weeks. However, several other standard sources including CDC and UNDP suggested an interval of 4 weeks. When both are given in options, it is recommended to mark 4 weeks as the correct answer.
Solution to Question 11:

Live vaccines should generally be avoided for 12 weeks following an injection of normal human immunoglobulin (Ig). If a live vaccine has already been administered, the injection of normal human Ig should be delayed for 2 weeks.
Note: In the case of measles alone, the recommended interval between administration of Measles immunoglobulins and Live measles vaccine is about 6 months in a non-immunocompromised individual and 8 months in an immunocompromised individual.
Solution to Question 12:
Polysaccharide-based vaccines stimulate an antibody response against the surface polysaccharide of the pathogenic-capsulated bacteria. The polysaccharide structure varies not only between bacteria of different species but also between different strains within a single species. Thus, a limitation of these vaccines is that the immune responses are serotype-specific.
If these vaccines are conjugated with proteins, they are given the capability of eliciting a stronger immune response. Multivalent formulations of both polysaccharide-based vaccines and conjugated vaccines are required to achieve protection against multiple serotypes.

Subunit vaccines are produced from macromolecules derived from immunogenic components of organisms by recombinant DNA technology. E.g., HPV vaccine (uses L1 major capsid protein) and hepatitis B vaccine (uses HBsAg).

However, asymptomatic infants who are HIV+ can be given BCG, provided the risk of contracting TB is high in that region. In areas of low TB prevalence or risk, the BCG vaccine is avoided.

WHO recommendations for administering live vaccines in symptomatic HIV+ patients:
Measles vaccine (or MMR) is allowed even in the symptomatic stage of HIV infection (except in the terminal phase), so as to prevent serious and life-threatening wild measles virus disease. Avoid MMR only if CD4+ < 15% (severely immunocompromised).

A frozen vaccine is used as a control vial and the vial suspected to be damaged by freezing is taken as the test vial.

Solution to Question 20:
The Rideal-Walker coefficient helps in assessing the power of a disinfectant relative to phenol.
It assesses this by determining the phenol coefficient (PC). A PC value of > 1 indicates that it is more effective than phenol. The higher the number, the greater its effectiveness in comparison to phenol and vice versa. Traditional organisms used to test the power of the disinfectant
include S. aureus and Salmonella enteric subtype typhi.
Phenol coefficient = The dilution of test disinfectant which kills microorganisms in a given time ÷ The dilution of phenol which kills the microorganism in the same time under identical conditions.
Other tests that are used for disinfectants are as follows:
Chick Martin test - modification of the Rideal-Walker test where disinfectants act in the presence of organic matter like feces or yeast to simulate natural conditions
Kelsey-Skyes test (capacity test) - tests the capacity of a disinfectant to retain its activity when used repeatedly.
In-use test - determines whether the chosen disinfectant is effective in actual hospital use
Joseph Lister first introduced phenol (carbolic acid) as an antiseptic to sterilize surgical instruments and clean wounds. Solution to Question 7:
The polysaccharide vaccine against Streptococcus pneumoniae (PPSV-23) is most beneficial for patients with sickle cell disease.
S. pneumoniae is an encapsulated organism that is detected by the spleen and is removed. However, in sickle cell disease, the sickled cells block the vessels in the spleen which results in splenic infarction. This hyposplenism results in an increased risk of pneumococcal infection. Hence, pneumococcal vaccine (PPSV-23) is given to these patients as a prophylactic measure to reduce this risk.
Solution to Question 8:
Mantoux or tuberculin testing is used to detect the prevalence of TB infection.
Infection of tuberculosis does not always lead to disease. In latent infections, the Mantoux test can be positive without any clinical symptoms. Therefore, the prevalence of TB infection is detected by the Mantoux test.
However, the prevalence of TB disease is confirmed by a sputum smear.
Solution to Question 9:
The above image shows an induration of >10 mm after 72 hrs of intradermal PPD injection suggesting a positive tuberculin test(TST), indicating recent or past infection.
In TST, 0.1 ml of PPD (purified protein derivative) containing 5 TU (tuberculosis unit) is injected intradermally and induration is read after 48-72 hours. An induration of 10 mm or more is considered positive in patients from countries with a high prevalence of tuberculosis. Surrounding erythema is not considered.
A positive tuberculin test indicates hypersensitivity to tuberculoprotein, denoting either latent infection with tubercle bacilli, or BCG immunization, or recent or past infection with or without clinical disease.
False positives may be seen in infections with related mycobacteria and false negatives in miliary tuberculosis, severely immunosuppressed states, etc.

Identification of new converters to the tuberculin test is a marker of the incidence of tuberculosis. Identification of all positives to the tuberculin test is a marker of the prevalence of tuberculosis.
Tuberculin conversion refers to the situation where an individual’s tuberculin skin test (TST) results in changes from negative (0–4 mm diameter induration) to positive (equal to or >10 mm diameter induration) within a 24-month period. TST conversion is considered presumptive evidence of acquired latent tuberculosis infection (LTBI) and potential risk for progression to active tuberculosis disease.

Detect – Treat – Prevent – Build approach for eliminating TB in India is part of the National Strategic Plan for TB (2017-2025). The components of this approach are:
Detect - Early identification of presumptive TB cases, at the first point of care, be it private or public sectors, and prompt diagnosis using high sensitivity diagnostic tests.
Treat - Provide sustained, equitable access to high quality TB treatment, care and support services.
Prevent - Prevent the emergence of TB in susceptible populations.
Build - Undertake critical management reforms, restructuring of HR and financial norms, pathways for private sector participation, in order to improve efficiency, effectiveness.

Solution to Question 7:
Slide (A) is a thin blood smear and slide (B) is a thick blood smear. Thin blood smears (slide A) are not used for estimating parasite concentration. They are used to detect the species of parasite.
Microscopy is the best method for the diagnosis of malaria due to its high sensitivity and specificity. Jaswant Singh Battacharya (JSB) stain is used for staining both thick and thin smears.
Thick smear is used to detect infection and estimate parasite concentration. The correct thickness is the thickness through which a newsprint is barely visible. It is prepared by slow-drying for 30 m nutes, which leads to hemolysis and distortion of the plasmodia morphology. Hence, species cannot be detected.
Thin smear is used to identify the particular infecting species of Plasmodium. It is prepared by air drying for 10 minutes and fixed in methanol. Thus, the plasmodia morphology is not distorted.

Solution to Question 17:
Lymphatic filariasis will be considered eliminated when the children born after the initiation of the programme are free from antigenemia. Antigenemia refers to the presence of adult filaria worms in the human body.
According to the Elimination of Lymphatic Filariasis (ELF) Programme, there are two criteria to consider elimination of lymphatic filariasis:
Children born after the initiation of the elimination programme are free from circulating antigenemia.
The number of microfilaria carriers is <1%.
Following the failure to achieve ELF by 2015, the target set to eliminate lymphatic filariasis by WHO was 2020. To achieve the same WHO recommended the use of triple therapy for lymphatic filariasis. It incorporated ivermectin along with diethylcarbamazine (DEC) and albendazole instead of the traditional DEC and albendazole therapy, for the elimination of transmission of lymphatic filariasis.
In 2021, WHO released the 'Road Map for Neglected Tropical Diseases (2021–2030)'. Under this, lymphatic filariasis is targeted for elimination as a public health problem by 2030.
In February 2023, the Ministry of Health & Family Welfare in India launched a nationwide Sarva Dawa Sevan or Mass Drug Administration (MDA) campaign to eliminate LF by 2027, aiming to achieve this goal three years ahead of the global target.

Solution to Question 21:
The two test protocol for the diagnosis of HIV consists of ELISA as the second test. If the initial ELISA is positive, a second ELISA is carried out. If the second ELISA is also positive, only then the case is reported to be positive.
Investigations involved in HIV testing strategies:
ELISA/ rapid tests.
Confirmatory tests with high specificity like western blot and line immunoassays are used in problem cases eg: indeterminate/ discordant cases of rapid tests.
In India, NACO provides western blot (WB) confirmatory testing only to resolve indeterminate results on previous serological testing. It is not used for routine confirmation after a positive result on screening tests. Drawbacks of WB include low rates of detection during acute
HIV infection and misclassification of HIV-2 infection.
Note: The western blot is used as a confirmatory test after 2 indeterminate primary tests (ELISA).
It is essentially the third test used and does not fit into the two test protocol.

The monetary benefit is measured in a cost-benefit analysis.
In cost-benefit analysis, the economic benefits of any program are compared with the cost of the program. The benefits are expressed in monetary terms to determine whether a given programme is economically sound and to select the best out of several alternate programmes.
The main drawback with this technique is that the benefits in the health field, as a result of a particular programme, cannot always be expressed in monetary terms. We generally express the benefit in terms of births or deaths prevented, or illness avoided or overcome.
In cost-effective analysis, the benefit is expressed in terms of results achieved. (Eg: number of lives saved or number of days free from disease).
Input-output analysis: how much input is needed to produce a unit amount of output. In the health field, input refers to all health service activities which consume resources (manpower, money, materials, and time); and output refers to useful outcomes such as cases treated, lives saved, or inoculations performed.

Solution to Question 2:
The death rate starts declining in stage 2 or the early expanding phase of the demographic cycle.
Solution to Question 3:
The birth rate starts declining in stage 3 or the late expanding phase of the demographic cycle. India is currently in this stage of the demographic cycle.
The year 1921 is called the year of the great divide in India. This is because, since 1921, the absolute number of people getting added to the population during each decade has been on the rise. This is the year in which India moved from stage 1 to stage 2 of the demographic cycle.
Solution to Question 4:
In the given scenario, country A is in stage 2 and country B is in stage 4 of the demographic cycle.
According to the given data, in country A, the high birth rate has remained unchanged with a decline in the death rate. This will result in an exponential increase in the population. This means country A is in the early expanding stage of the demographic cycle.
In country B, the low birth rate and death rates have remained unchanged. Thus, the population will attain a plateau phase and remain stationary. This means country B is in the low stationary stage of the demographic cycle.
Solution to Question 5:
In stage 5 of the demographic cycle, the birth rate falls below the death rate.
In this stage, the death rate attains a low stable rate while the birth rate keeps declining. Thus, the curve of the birth rate will cross the curve of the death rate in a graph of the demographic cycle and falls further below.
The demographic gap is negative and the population is declining. So, this stage is known as the declining stage.
Solution to Question 6:

Solution to Question 7:
The demographic gap starts increasing in stage 2 and starts decreasing in stage 3.
The demographic gap refers to the difference between birth rate and death rate which develops when a country undergoes a demographic transition.
In stage 2 of the demographic cycle, the death rate declines but the birth rate remains unchanged. Hence, the demographic gap increases and reaches a maximum by the end of stage 2. In stage 3, both the death rate and birth rate are declining so the demographic gap starts decreasing.

The demographic gap starts increasing and becomes maximum in the early expanding phase of the demographic cycle.
Solution to Question 9:
The marked stage is the late expanding phase (stage 3) of the demographic cycle. A demographic gift or demographic dividend is seen in this stage.
This refers to the presence of a higher number of economically productive individuals (young and middle-aged adults) in the population due to a higher birth rate in the previous demographic phase (phase 2). India is currently experiencing the demographic gift.
The birth rate starts declining alongside a death rate that continues to fall in stage 3 causing a decline in the demographic gap. The death rate declines further and the birth rate falls in this stage.
Solution to Question 10:
The phenomenon of a demographic trap is seen maximally in the early expanding stage (stage 2).
This phenomenon refers to a period in which there is high fertility and birth rate and a declining death rate. The population grows exponentially in this stage and this growing population exceeds the national or regional carrying capacity. Countries in this stage are said to be caught in
a demographic trap.

The patient should be advised to eat whole grains since it has a low glycemic index (GI).
GI is a number representing the relative ability of a carbohydrate food to increase the level of glucose in the blood. It is calculated by comparing the test carbohydrate to the standard (glucose or white bread). This measure has practical use in the management of diabetes and obesity.
Low GI foods – most fruits and vegetables, whole grains, pasta foods, beans, and lentils.
Moderate GI foods – sucrose, basmati rice, and brown rice.
High GI foods – corn flakes, baked potatoes, white bread, potatoes, watermelon, candies, and syrupy foods.

The renal feed of a patient suffering from end-stage renal disease should ideally be low volume, high calories.
Dietary factors may have an effect on the progression of kidney disease and its complications. A low-volume feed is preferred in order to avoid:
Sodium and volume overload
Hyperkalemia
Hyperphosphatemia
Accumulation of toxic metabolites of protein degradation
A high-calorie feed is preferred in order to combat the patient's risk of malnutrition and wasting seen in ESRD.

Role is the function or duties assumed by a person of a particular society.

Solution to Question 15:
Microfiltration is a lower-pressure membrane process used for the treatment of water.
Membrane processes are employed in the large scale treatment of water. They are classified as high-pressure processes and lower-pressure processes.
High-pressure processes:
Reverse osmosis - Rejects monovalent ions and organic molecules of molecular weight > 50 daltons. It is most commonly used for desalination of brackish water and sea water. The membrane pore size is < 0.002 µm.
Nanofiltration - Allows monovalent ions such as sodium or potassium to pass but rejects a high proportion of divalent ions like calcium and magnesium and some higher molecular weight organics. The membrane pore size ranges from 0.001 – 0.01 µm.
Lower-pressure processes:
Ultrafiltration - Rejects organic molecules of molecular weight > 800 daltons. The membrane pore size ranges from 0.002 - 0.003 µm.
Microfiltration - Rejects colloidal and suspended material. It does not separate molecules and is usually used before reverse osmosis. The membrane pore size ranges from 0.01 – 12 µm.

Solution to Question 1:
Ventilation involves the quality control of incoming air but not quality control of outgoing air.
It also involves the replacement of vitiated air(air with decreased oxygen content) by a supply of fresh outdoor air. It aims to provide a comfortable thermal environment and reduce the risk of infections.
Solution to Question 2:

Solution to Question 3:
Ventilation provided by wind blowing through a space is called perflation. Ventilation can be broadly classified as natural and mechanical:
Natural ventilation includes:
Perflation is the ventilation of a space achieved by allowing wind to blow through it and removing the obstacles for this to happen (e.g., opening windows and doors).
Aspiration occurs when there is an obstruction as wind bypasses it and creates a suction action
Diffusion is the passage of air through small spaces or openings
Cross-ventilation is when air is allowed a natural path through the space by providing openings at appropriate places, opposite each other.
The drawback of natural ventilation is that regulation of air quality is not possible. Mechanical ventilation includes:
Exhaust ventilation utilizes exhaust fans placed high up near the roof on the external walls. A vacuum is created by which fresh air enters the ventilated space.
Plenum ventilation uses centrifugal fans to blow fresh air into the room and create a positive pressure, by which vitiated air is pushed out.
Balanced ventilation is the combination of both exhaust and plenum methods of ventilation.
Air conditioning can be done through mechanical ventilation. It is the simultaneous control of all or at least three factors that influence air quality in a confined room or space. These factors include temperature, humidity, air movement, distribution, dust, bacteria, odours and toxic gases.
Solution to Question 4:
Perflation is not a type of mechanical ventilation. It is a type of natural ventilation. Ventilation can be broadly classified as natural and mechanical:
Natural ventilation includes:
Perflation is the ventilation of a space achieved by allowing wind to blow through it and removing the obstacles for this to happen (e.g., opening windows and doors).
Aspiration occurs when there is an obstruction as wind bypasses it and creates a suction action.
Diffusion is the passage of air through small spaces or openings.
Cross-ventilation is when air is allowed a natural path through the space by providing openings at appropriate places, opposite each other.
The drawback of natural ventilation is that regulation of air quality is not possible. Mechanical ventilation includes:
Exhaust ventilation utilizes exhaust fans placed high up near the roof on the external walls. A vacuum is created by which fresh air enters the ventilated space.
Plenum ventilation uses centrifugal fans to blow fresh air into the room and create a positive pressure, by which vitiated air is pushed out.
Balanced ventilation is the combination of both exhaust and plenum methods of ventilation.
Air conditioning can be done through mechanical ventilation. It is the simultaneous control of all or at least three factors that influence air quality in a confined room or space. These factors include temperature, humidity, air movement, distribution, dust, bacteria, odours and toxic gases.

Deterministic effects on the fetus are not seen below 5 rads or 50 mSv of radiation. Dose limits of radiation exposure are:

Solution to Question 19:
The 10 days rule in radiation was related to pregnancy. It is aimed at preventing unintentional exposure of the embryo or fetus to radiation.
This rule states that if a radiograph is being done on the abdomen or pelvis of a woman in her childbearing age, then it should be done during the 10 days following the onset of menstruation.
In most situations, there is growing evidence that strict adherence to the "ten-day rule" may be unnecessarily restrictive. Since organogenesis starts 3 to 5 weeks post-conception, it was felt that radiation exposure in early pregnancy couldn't result in malformation. Based on this, it was suggested to do away with the 10-day rule and replace it with a 28-day rule. This means that radiological examination if justified, can be carried throughout the cycle until a period is missed.

Controlled tipping is the most satisfactory method of refuse disposal when suitable land is available.
In this method, waste materials are placed in a trench, compacted, and covered with earth at the end of the day. This method is also called a sanitary landfill. Chemical, bacteriological and physical changes occur in the buried refuse with temperatures rising to over 60 degrees Celsius within 7 days.

Trench method: Done in places where level ground is available
Ramp method: Well suited where the terrain is moderately sloping

Solution to Question 6:
The Bangalore method of composting is an anaerobic process.
Composting is a method of combined disposal of refuse and nightsoil. In this process, organic matter is broken down into compost. It has manure value and few or no disease-causing pathogens.
Bangalore method is an anaerobic method and is also called hot fermentation
process. Trenches with a depth of not more than 90cm are used for this. This is done by spreading a layer of refuse (15 cm thick) at the bottom of the trench and nightsoil (5cm thick) is added next. Layers of refuse and nightsoil are added alternatively till the heap rises to 30cm above ground level. The heap is then covered with excavated earth. At the end of 4 – 6 months, decomposition will be completed.
Mechanical composting is an aerobic process. In this method, compost is manufactured on a large scale by processing raw materials and turning out a finished product. The refuse is first cleared of salvageable materials. It is then pulverised to reduce the size of particles to less than 2 inches. The pulverised refuse is then mixed with sewage, sludge or nightsoil in a rotating machine and incubated.

Algae
Saprophytic bacteria
Sunligh

Solution to Question 8:
Barosinusitis occurs in decompression sickness or Caisson's disease. It is due to the sudden expansion of air in the sinuses.
It can be seen in:
Divers who ascend rapidly from deep-sea (high pressure) to the surface of the earth (low pressure)
Pilots of unpressurized aircraft or mountaineers who rapidly ascended from the surface of the earth (high-pressure zone) to a high altitude (low-pressure zone)
Under high pressure, gases get compressed, and their solubility increases. When a person is in deep-sea (high-pressure zone) for a long time, an increased amount of nitrogen gets dissolved in his body. When he suddenly comes back to the surface (atmospheric pressure or a low-pressure zone), the solubility of gases decreases and they escape from the dissolved state forming nitrogen bubbles.
These bubbles can cause sudden expansion of air in various parts of the body such as the middle ear (barotitis), sinuses (barosinusitis), beneath teeth (barodontalgia), intestinal loops (abdominal distension), and emphysema.
N trogen bubbles can also cause chokes (dyspnoea), bends (joint pain), and prickles (nerve rritation).
The definitive treatment for Caisson's disease is recompression.

Solution to Question 6:
Socio-environmental approach is not an approach to health education. There are four approaches to health education:
Regulatory approach- external control or laws placed on people by the government. Ex: Child Marriage Act, No smoking in public places, Helmet law
Service approach- government aims at providing health services to the people at their doorsteps. Its drawback is that people will not accept a service, even if it is offered free of cost unless it is based on their felt needs. Ex: Government provided latrines free of cost yet people did not use them because its need was not felt
Health education approach- creates awareness of health needs and problems. Awareness leads to motivation which includes the stages of interest, evaluation, and decision-making. It is followed by acceptance of the new idea which becomes part of his existing values, known as internalization. Ex: Adoption of ORS for diarrhea
Primary health care approach- delivery of health services with the active involvement of people. Principles of community participation and intersectoral coordination are stressed here. Its objective is to help individuals become self-reliant in health matters. Ex: People receive guidance from healthcare providers (Rogi Kalyana Samiti, Mahila Arogya Samiti).

Social intervention model: focuses on changing the social environment which subsequently shapes the behavior of individual and the community.

The Indian Public Health Standards (IPHS) guidelines are a code of standards for uniformity in health facilities in the Indian public health system, under the National Health Mission (NHM), Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MoHFW), India. It aims to provide guidance on the infrastructure, human resources, drugs, diagnostics, equipment, quality, and governance requirements for delivering health services at all levels of facilities in the system.
The 2022 edition of IPHS mainly concentrates on comprehensive primary health care, increasing the human workforce, decentralized access to healthcare, and better implementation of universal health coverage.

In a district having a population of 20 lakhs, the number of beds the district public health system should have is given as follows: 2000 essential and 4000 desirable.
According to IPHS 2022 norms for the number of beds in district hospitals, 1 bed per 1000 population is essential and 2 beds per thousand population would be desirable.
Therefore, in a population of 20,00,000 the district public health system should have 2000 essential and 4000 desirable beds.

Solution to Question 1:
A study to determine the mean height of children is an example of a descriptive statistical study.
Descriptive statistics are the statistical methods that merely organize, describe or summarize the actual data available. For example, a study determining the mean blood pressure of patients visiting a PHC on a single day.
Analytical statistics are the second major category of epidemiological studies, after descriptive statistics. The objective of an analytical study is to test the hypothesis.
An observational study is an empiric investigation in which the objective is to establish a relationship between cause and effect. It falls under the category of analytical statistics.
It is performed when controlled experimentation cannot be feasibly used to determine a hypothesis. For example, in the case of cigarette smoking causing lung cancer, it would be unethical and not feasible to conduct a controlled experiment. So, an observational study is preferred.
Inferential statistics involve inductive reasoning i.e., generalizing observations to a population after having observed only a sample. An example of such a study would be a study determining the expected success rate of vasectomy
Theoretical statistics is a mathematical approach to describe something, predict events, or analyze the relationship between things. Some of the concepts of theoretical statistics are mean, median, mode, standard deviation and correlation.
Solution to Question 2:
An element is a single observation in a study. For example, in a study of blood pressure values, the blood pressure value of one person is an element.
In a statistical study, the population refers to the group about which information is to be gathered. The composition of the population in terms of its age, sex, occupation, cultural characters, etc need to be defined before a study is conducted. The population need not consist of just people but can also be made of measurements. For example, in a study of blood glucose measurements in Indians, the population consists of the blood glucose measurements.
The part/subset of the population, which is being studied is known as a sample. For example, in a questionnaire-based study on cervical cancer in a population, the sample would include females attending the out-patient departments of a hospital. This is a subset of the entire population.

If the probability of an event occurring is 1, it means there is an absolute certainty that the event will occur.
The addition rule and multiplication rule can be used to calculate the probability of an event. The addition rule is used to calculate the combined probability of the occurrence of two or more mutually exclusive events. The multiplication rule is used to calculate the combined probability of two or more statistically independent events occurring together.
Probability values range from 0 (no probability) to 1 (absolute certainty). So negative value of p is not possible.
Since p is the probability of an event occurring and q is the probability of the event not occurring, q = 1 - p
Solution to Question 4:
Binomial distribution is widely used in genetic counseling.
Binomial distribution helps determine the probability of occurance of a specific combination of mutually exclusive independent events. In a binomial distribution, there are only two possible events like Yes/No or Male/Female or Alive/Dead. The results of the distribution gives the probabilities of obtaining an exact number of successes in a series of independent trials.
For example, the inheritence of cystic fibrosis follows a binomial distribution. There are:
Two possible events - inheriting the disease/ not inheriting it
Events are mutually exclusive - one person cannot both have the disease and not have it
Independent possibilities - if one child has inherited it, this will not affect if the other child will inherit it.
The physician using this technique can explain to the patients the probabilities of their children suffering from the disease.

Solution to Question 1:
Mental health is a state of well-being in which an individual realizes his or her own abilities and not merely the absence of mental illness. It is the ability to cope with stress, be productive, and contribute to the community.
Mental disorders are universal and are not specific to any particular group. They are associated with hereditary (family history of psychiatric disorders) and environmental factors. Substance abuse and alcohol addiction are considered types of mental illness.
Solution to Question 2:

The factors leading to mental health illnesses include:
Organic - cerebral arteriosclerosis, neoplasms, endocrine, metabolic and chronic diseases
Hereditary - schizophrenia
Socio-pathological factors - worries, anxiety, frustration, emotional stress, tension, unhappy marriages, broken homes, poverty, industrialization, urbanization, changing family structure,
population mobility, economic insecurity, cruelty, rejection, neglect.
Environmental - environmental toxins, substance abuse, radiation, nutritional factors, minera deficiencies, infectious diseases during prenatal, perinatal, and postnatal periods (like rubella), road traffic accidents.

Tertiary prevention - measures to reduce the duration of mental illness as well family and community stresses to prevent further breakdown and disruption

This act encourages the mobilization of resources to improve mental health care across the country as well as reduce stigma and improve social inclusion/support for those with mental illness. It also has provisions to improve outcomes and protect their rights.

Young and middle-aged adults between 18-45 years

Autosomal recessive disorders usually manifest in childhood or earlier.
Heterozygotes are unaffected by the disease. When both parents are heterozygous, each offspring (both male and female) has a 1:4 chance of being affected. Examples of autosomal recessive disorders include several inborn errors of metabolism like phenylketonuria, cystic fibrosis, and galactosemia.
Solution to Question 5:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hemophilia A. It is an X-linked recessive disorder. Hemophilia is of two types:
Hemophilia A - due to mutations in the F8 gene leading to factor VIII deficiency
Hemophilia B - due to mutations in the F9 gene leading to factor IX deficiency
Affected children often present with prolonged bleeding after procedures like circumcision or major bleeds like intracranial hemorrhages. When the child begins to walk, bleeding into the joint (hemarthrosis) may occur, causing painful swellings and reddening.
Laboratory investigations show elevated aPTT, with normal PT and platelet count. It is treated by the administration of factor VIII or factor IX concentrates.
